supporting.text: A square meets the definition of a rectangle as it has four sides and four right angles.

attacks.text: A square meets the definition of a rectangle as it has four sides and four right angles.
A square is a special case of a rectangle, but calling it a rectangle ignores its unique properties like equal side lengths.
Mathematical definitions prioritize inclusion over uniqueness; a square is still a rectangle by definition, regardless of additional properties.
In practical contexts, calling a square a rectangle can cause confusion, as people expect rectangles to have unequal side lengths.
Mathematical terminology should not be altered based on layperson expectations; precision in definitions is more important.

supporting.text: All properties of a rectangle (opposite sides equal, all angles 90 degrees) are satisfied by a square.

attacks.text: All properties of a rectangle (opposite sides equal, all angles 90 degrees) are satisfied by a square.
A square has additional constraints (all sides equal) not required by the definition of a rectangle, making it a special case rather than a general rectangle.
Mathematical definitions classify squares as a subset of rectangles, meaning all squares are rectangles but not all rectangles are squares.
In practical applications, the distinction between squares and rectangles is often important, so treating them as identical can lead to errors.

supporting.text: In geometry, a square is classified as a special case of a rectangle where all sides are of equal length.

attacks.text: In geometry, a square is classified as a special case of a rectangle where all sides are of equal length.
A square has additional properties (equal sides and angles) that are not required for a rectangle, making it a distinct shape.
The definition of a rectangle includes all quadrilaterals with four right angles, which inherently includes squares as a subset.
In practical applications, treating squares as rectangles can lead to confusion due to their stricter constraints.
Mathematical definitions prioritize logical consistency over practical convenience, and the classification holds under formal geometric rules.

supporting.text: The inclusive definition of a rectangle in mathematics explicitly includes squares as a subset of rectangles.

attacks.text: The inclusive definition of a rectangle in mathematics explicitly includes squares as a subset of rectangles.
In some informal contexts, squares and rectangles are treated as distinct shapes, ignoring the mathematical definition.
Informal usage does not override formal mathematical definitions, which are universally accepted in academic and professional settings.
Some educational materials for young children introduce squares and rectangles as separate categories to simplify learning.
Simplified educational approaches are later corrected with formal definitions, ensuring accurate mathematical understanding.

supporting.text: Every square can be considered a rectangle, but not every rectangle is a square, indicating the hierarchical relationship.

attacks.text: Every square can be considered a rectangle, but not every rectangle is a square, indicating the hierarchical relationship.
A square requires all sides to be equal and all angles to be 90 degrees, while a rectangle only requires angles to be 90 degrees, making the definitions fundamentally different.
The definition of a rectangle includes squares as a special case, which means squares inherently satisfy the conditions of being a rectangle.
In practical applications, treating squares as rectangles can lead to confusion because squares have additional constraints not present in general rectangles.
Mathematical definitions are hierarchical by nature, and recognizing squares as a subset of rectangles is consistent with standard geometric classification.

supporting.text: The mathematical axioms for rectangles do not exclude quadrilaterals with equal side lengths, thus encompassing squares.

attacks.text: The mathematical axioms for rectangles do not exclude quadrilaterals with equal side lengths, thus encompassing squares.
While squares are technically rectangles, colloquial usage often distinguishes them as separate shapes, leading to potential confusion.
Mathematical definitions should not be conflated with colloquial usage, as precision is critical in formal contexts.
Some geometric systems define rectangles strictly as quadrilaterals with unequal adjacent sides, excluding squares.
Standard Euclidean geometry universally accepts squares as a subset of rectangles, making specialized definitions non-authoritative.
